633
cal parallel for àyQzxtvoavxa at Sparta ( or elsewhere to the reviewer's knowledge ),  and ( 5 ) that dating by the Actian era,  as here,  is unknown at Sparta,  but was in use in more than one Messenian city.  It would be more natural to assign this inscription to some place in Messenia,  perhaps of moderate size,  where the generosity of the recipient,  who is honoured for making a gift of ten denarii to each of the Gerontes and entertaining the whole city to a banquet,  would be thought worthier of commemoration as regards the former act and less improbable as regards the latter than if they had taken place at Sparta.  This conclusion seems fatal to the ingenious idea that the date of this text ( A.  D.  163 ) marks the end of one of the 81 - year cycles reckoned,  as we have seen above,  from the year of the Lycurgan Reforms,  809 B.  C.  ( 12 x8i = 972 ). 
These examples will suffice to show that readers may easily be led astray if they follow the author's guidance in the field of epigraphy without verifying the details for themselves as far as possible.  ( There is less risk of their accepting the perverted interpretation of No / nog ßamXsvg on p.  4751 ) In the field of philology they will be wise to await expert opinion on the reconstructed form of the Rhetra,  offered with many most ingenious suggestions on pp.  477—89.  The reviewer,  claiming no expert knowledge,  may at least record his doubts on the subject of equating SvQiiaia with * * Ед / и€1а to justify the old interpretation of SvÀÀanov as ^EÀÀaviov,  and of restoring the famous crux at the end of ) >Part II« so as to read ( d ) afia ) ôâv ( xv ) Q ( av rjfiTjv »the citizens are to have the authority«.  But is xvgia in this sense ever found before the fourth century,  and is it at all likely that of the two gammas in this passage one should be a dialect form for delta and the other for kappa^\ and can yo - for хлу be matched in any form of Doric dialect?  Finally,  eccentric though the utterances of the Delphic Oracle often were,  it is not very easy to believe in the injunction »to hold Apollo's gatherings season after season between the pelicans and the place of wild goats «.  True that the connection of HvaKiobvog with wild goats seems quite likely,  but asya landmark it seems inconveniently vague.  Could it not refer to the region in which lay the Sanctuary of Artemis Knagia ( Paus.  iii.  18,  4 ),  for which the area N.  - W.  of the Acropolis is a possible site''? 
10. 
This lengthy discussion,  it is hoped,  will not have left in doubt the reviewer's considered opinion that this is a work of very considerable
6.  The Hcsychius gloss ôupovqa — y & pvQa^ Лахшгед,  points in the opposite direction,  cf.  also BS A.  xxvi.  p.  224. 
7.  Cf.  BSA.  xxx.  p.  234 ( tile - stamps from this sanctuary ).

label: Chrimes: Ancient Sparta
